abstract: Two musky steroids, and higher levels of odorous acids, distinguish the body odors of adolescents and tots.
snippet: Two musky steroids, and higher levels of odorous acids, distinguish the body odors of adolescents and tots.
lead_paragraph: Few parents would describe the smells emanating from their adolescent children as redolent of sandalwood. But one of the distinct components of teenage body odor is a compound that evokes that warm, woody fragrance, according to a small new study, which compared the scents of adolescents to those of infants and toddlers.

headline.main: Toddlers Smell Like Flowers, Teens Smell 'Goatlike,' Study Finds

abstract: A Johns Hopkins scientist was known for rigorous studies of psychedelics. Was he a true believer?
snippet: A Johns Hopkins scientist was known for rigorous studies of psychedelics. Was he a true believer?
lead_paragraph: Before he died last year, Roland Griffiths was arguably the world's most famous psychedelics researcher. Since 2006, his work has suggested that psilocybin, found in magic mushrooms, can induce mystical experiences, and that those experiences, in turn, can help treat anxiety, depression, addiction and the terror of death.

headline.main: The Psychedelic Evangelist

abstract: The studies, pulled because of copied data, illustrate the sluggishness of scientific publishers to address serious errors, experts said.
snippet: The studies, pulled because of copied data, illustrate the sluggishness of scientific publishers to address serious errors, experts said.
lead_paragraph: Scientists in a prominent cancer lab at Columbia University have now had four studies retracted and a stern note added to a fifth accusing it of “severe abuse of the scientific publishing system,” the latest fallout from research misconduct allegations recently leveled against several leading cancer scientists.

headline.main: More Studies by Columbia Cancer Researchers Are Retracted
headline.print_headline: More Cancer Studies By Columbia Scientists Are Pulled by Journals

abstract: An archaeological site in Ethiopia revealed the oldest-known arrowheads and the remnants of a major volcanic eruption.
snippet: An archaeological site in Ethiopia revealed the oldest-known arrowheads and the remnants of a major volcanic eruption.
lead_paragraph: In 2002, a crew of paleoanthropologists were working in northwestern Ethiopia when they came across chipped stones and fossilized animal bones — telltale signs of a place where ancient people had once lived.

headline.main: Fossil Trove From 74,000 Years Ago Points to Remarkably Adaptive Humans

abstract: A number of case studies published after recent total solar eclipses highlight the importance of safe viewing.
snippet: A number of case studies published after recent total solar eclipses highlight the importance of safe viewing.
lead_paragraph: A young woman visited New York Eye & Ear Infirmary of Mount Sinai Hospital shortly after the eclipse of Aug. 21, 2017. She told Dr. Avnish Deobhakta, an ophthalmologist, that she had a black area in her vision, and then drew a crescent shape for him on a piece of paper.

headline.main: Eclipses Injured Their Eyes, and the World Never Looked the Same

abstract: Michel Talagrand of France has credited a brush with blindness for leading to the work that resulted in his recognition by the math equivalent of the Nobel Prize.
snippet: Michel Talagrand of France has credited a brush with blindness for leading to the work that resulted in his recognition by the math equivalent of the Nobel Prize.
lead_paragraph: A French mathematician is the recipient of this year's Abel Prize, the math equivalent of the Nobel, for advances in understanding randomness in the universe — the heights of ocean waves crashing on a beach, the weights of babies, the ups and downs of the stock market — work that has found use in mathematical physics and statistics.

headline.main: Abel Prize Awarded for Studies of Universe's Randomness
headline.print_headline: $700,000 Prize Awarded  For Randomness Studies

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters

abstract: The superbly preserved remains of a Bronze Age settlement offer a glimpse of a “colorful, rich, varied” domestic life circa 850 B.C.
snippet: The superbly preserved remains of a Bronze Age settlement offer a glimpse of a “colorful, rich, varied” domestic life circa 850 B.C.
lead_paragraph: Three millenniums ago, a small, prosperous farming community briefly flourished in the freshwater marshes of eastern England. The inhabitants lived in a clutch of thatched roundhouses built on wooden stilts above a channel of the River Nene, which empties into the North Sea. They wore clothes of fine flax linen, with pleats and tasseled hems; bartered for glass and amber beads imported from places as far-flung as present-day Iran; drank from delicate clay poppyhead cups; dined on leg of boar and honey-glazed venison, and fed table scraps to their dogs.

headline.main: This Was Village Life in Britain 3,000 Years Ago
headline.print_headline: Under Centuries of Silt, a Vivid View of Bronze Age Life

abstract: A new study of camera-trap images complicates the idea that all wildlife thrived during the Covid lockdowns.
snippet: A new study of camera-trap images complicates the idea that all wildlife thrived during the Covid lockdowns.
lead_paragraph: In the early months of the Covid pandemic, when every bit of news seemed bleak, there was one heartwarming narrative that took hold: With humans stuck in their homes, the world was safe again for wild animals, which could now wander freely through cities, parking lots or fields that once might have been crowded with people.

headline.main: Where the Wild Things Went During the Pandemic
headline.print_headline: Covid Set Off Animals' Wary Dance

abstract: The observation suggests that seals join cobras, archerfish and other animals known to spit, although researchers can only speculate about the reason for the mammal's expectoration.
snippet: The observation suggests that seals join cobras, archerfish and other animals known to spit, although researchers can only speculate about the reason for the mammal's expectoration.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 3, 2022, Clare Jacobs, a bird-watcher, was delighted to spot a rare white-tailed eagle, or Haliaeetus albicilla, at a nature reserve on the Isle of Wight in southern England. These birds, also known as sea eagles or ernes, vanished from the region some 250 years ago, but more than two dozen birds have been released on the island since 2019.

headline.main: A Seal's Spray Adds a Chapter to the Science of Spitting

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Isle of Wight Natural History and Archaeological Society (Journal)

abstract: April 8 could be your best opportunity to see a total solar eclipse for decades. But if clouds fill the sky, your shot at seeing the spectacle could be lost.
snippet: April 8 could be your best opportunity to see a total solar eclipse for decades. But if clouds fill the sky, your shot at seeing the spectacle could be lost.
lead_paragraph: April 8 could be your best opportunity to see a total solar eclipse for decades. But if clouds fill the sky, your shot at seeing the spectacle could be lost.

headline.main: What's the Cloud Outlook for Eclipse Day? See if History Is on Your Side.

byline.original: By Josh Katz, K.K. Rebecca Lai and William B. Davis

abstract: A large analysis in Canada finds that teenagers who had babies were twice as likely to die before age 31.
snippet: A large analysis in Canada finds that teenagers who had babies were twice as likely to die before age 31.
lead_paragraph: Teen pregnancy increases the chances that a young woman will drop out of school and struggle with poverty, research has shown. Teenagers are also more likely to develop serious medical complications during pregnancy.

headline.main: Teen Pregnancy Linked to Premature Death, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Study Links Dying Young To Pregnancy As Teenager

abstract: Many patients are reluctant to undergo colonoscopies or conduct at-home fecal tests. Doctors see potential in another screening method.
snippet: Many patients are reluctant to undergo colonoscopies or conduct at-home fecal tests. Doctors see potential in another screening method.
lead_paragraph: Early detection of colon cancer can prevent a majority of deaths from this disease, possibly as much as 73 percent of them. But just 50 to 75 percent of middle-aged and older adults who should be screened regularly are being tested.

headline.main: A Blood Test Shows Promise for Early Colon Cancer Detection
headline.print_headline: New Test May Spot Colon Cancer in Early Stage

abstract: A new study argues that the change brought these females an evolutionary advantage — and perhaps did the same for humans.
snippet: A new study argues that the change brought these females an evolutionary advantage — and perhaps did the same for humans.
lead_paragraph: Menopause is all too familiar to women, but in other species it's remarkably rare. Last year, scientists reported that females in a single population of chimpanzees live long past their reproductive years. But aside from chimps and humans, researchers have found clear evidence of menopause in only five species — all of them whales.

headline.main: Why Do Whales Go Through Menopause?

abstract: Scientists never imagined that the blind cave salamanders called olms willingly left their caves. But at numerous aboveground springs, there they were.
snippet: Scientists never imagined that the blind cave salamanders called olms willingly left their caves. But at numerous aboveground springs, there they were.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have discovered that blind cave salamanders in northern Italy leave their underground homes to go on expeditions to the surface.

headline.main: Subterranean 'Baby Dragons' Are Revealed to Sneak to the Surface

abstract: A new study reveals that cicadas can discharge urine with far more force than their size would suggest. This spring's output could be significant.
snippet: A new study reveals that cicadas can discharge urine with far more force than their size would suggest. This spring's output could be significant.
lead_paragraph: This spring, when the ground temperature hits 64 degrees Fahrenheit, trillions of cicadas will dig their way up from beneath the soil across the Southern and Midwestern United States. In a rare so-called double emergence, two distinct cicada broods — one on a 13-year life cycle and the other on a 17-year one — will take to the trees to sing, eat and mate.

headline.main: When Cicadas Emerge, Things Might Get a Little Wet
headline.print_headline: Going With the Flow: With Emergence of Cicadas, Things Might Get a Little Wet

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

abstract: Given troves of data about genes and cells, A.I. models have made some surprising discoveries. What could they teach us someday?
snippet: Given troves of data about genes and cells, A.I. models have made some surprising discoveries. What could they teach us someday?
lead_paragraph: In 1889, a French doctor named Francois-Gilbert Viault climbed down from a mountain in the Andes, drew blood from his arm and inspected it under a microscope. Dr. Viault's red blood cells, which ferry oxygen, had surged 42 percent. He had discovered a mysterious power of the human body: When it needs more of these crucial cells, it can make them on demand.

headline.main: A.I. Is Learning What It Means to Be Alive
headline.print_headline: A.I. and Being Alive

abstract: At SXSW, a documentary traces the arc of plastics in our lives, and highlights evolving research of the potential harm of its presence in our bodies.
snippet: At SXSW, a documentary traces the arc of plastics in our lives, and highlights evolving research of the potential harm of its presence in our bodies.
lead_paragraph: It's been more than five decades since Dustin Hoffman's character in “The Graduate” was offered a kernel of wisdom about the path to prosperity.

headline.main: Microplastics Are a Big Problem, a New Film Warns
headline.print_headline: Microplastics Are Found All Over, Even in Human Brains, Film Warns

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: South by Southwest Music and Media Conference

abstract: While the sentinel trees of Northern Lebanon may not be as old as some traditions hold, one tree might be more than 1,000 years old.
snippet: While the sentinel trees of Northern Lebanon may not be as old as some traditions hold, one tree might be more than 1,000 years old.
lead_paragraph: Olive trees are common in Northern Lebanon, but in the village of Bshaaleh, a handful look downright ancient. Their branches grow in wildly unpredictable directions, and the trees' gray, gnarled trunks are shot through with holes and crevasses large enough to hide a sleeping child. Many people believe these sentinel trees are thousands of years old. They are known as “Noah trees” because of some people's belief that the trees are the source of the olive branch carried by the dove back to Noah's ark.

headline.main: These May Be the Oldest Olive Trees in the World
headline.print_headline: Half a Millennium  Is Par for the Course

abstract: Amphibians called caecilians add cloacal secretions of a nutritious material similar to milk to their numerous quirks, according to a new study.
snippet: Amphibians called caecilians add cloacal secretions of a nutritious material similar to milk to their numerous quirks, according to a new study.
lead_paragraph: Motherhood takes many shapes. Most vertebrates, like birds, reptiles, amphibians and fish, reproduce by laying eggs filled with nourishing yolk that their offspring use as an initial source of nutrition before hatching. Mammals change the game by giving birth to live young and feeding them fatty, sugary milk as they get on their feet.

headline.main: Bizarre, Wormlike and Oozing Milk for Their Babies
headline.print_headline: Slimy Worms: Wormlike and Oozing Milk For Their Batch of Babes

abstract: A large study of “discordant twins,” in which only one suffered abuse or neglect, adds to evidence linking childhood trauma to adult illness.
snippet: A large study of “discordant twins,” in which only one suffered abuse or neglect, adds to evidence linking childhood trauma to adult illness.
lead_paragraph: Twins are a bonanza for research psychologists. In a field perpetually seeking to tease out the effects of genetics, environment and life experience, they provide a natural controlled experiment as their paths diverge, subtly or dramatically, through adulthood.

headline.main: One Twin Was Hurt, the Other Was Not. Their Adult Mental Health Diverged.
headline.print_headline: One Twin Was Hurt, the Other Was Not. As Adults, Their Mental Health Diverged.

abstract: Media accounts of a German man's extreme vaccination history spurred researchers to analyze his immune responses.
snippet: Media accounts of a German man's extreme vaccination history spurred researchers to analyze his immune responses.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, German doctors stumbled across news reports of a man being investigated for receiving scores of coronavirus vaccines with no medical explanation.

headline.main: After 217 Covid Vaccines, Man Had No Side Effects and Robust Immunity
headline.print_headline: Doctors Study Man Who Had 217 Covid Shots, and Find Lots of Antibodies

abstract: A new paper challenges the idea that the large, carnivorous Spinosaurus dived after prey rather than wading and plucking it out of the water.
snippet: A new paper challenges the idea that the large, carnivorous Spinosaurus dived after prey rather than wading and plucking it out of the water.
lead_paragraph: Spinosaurus was one of the largest carnivorous dinosaurs, and it ate fish. That much paleontologists agree on.

headline.main: A Swimming Dinosaur? Maybe Not, Study Says
headline.print_headline: Doubts Raised About Idea of a Swimming Dinosaur

abstract: The results could shed light on why the animals rarely get cancer. But the researchers' ultimate goal of bringing back woolly mammoths is still aspirational.
snippet: The results could shed light on why the animals rarely get cancer. But the researchers' ultimate goal of bringing back woolly mammoths is still aspirational.
lead_paragraph: When the biotechnology firm Colossal started in 2021, it set an eyebrow-raising goal: to genetically engineer elephants with hair and other traits found on extinct woolly mammoths.

headline.main: Scientists Create Elephant Stem Cells in the Lab
headline.print_headline: Elephant Stem Cells Created in the Lab

abstract: New research is stirring interest in ibogaine, which appears to help ease the agony of detox and prevent relapse. Used in other countries, it remains illegal in the U.S.
snippet: New research is stirring interest in ibogaine, which appears to help ease the agony of detox and prevent relapse. Used in other countries, it remains illegal in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: Ibogaine, a formidable psychedelic made from the root of a shrub native to Central Africa, is not for the timid. It unleashes a harrowing trip that can last more than 24 hours, and the drug can cause sudden cardiac arrest and death.

headline.main: Powerful Psychedelic Gains Renewed Attention as a Treatment for Opioid Addiction
headline.print_headline: Psychedelic Approach

abstract: Some researchers hope the drug, still illegal in the United States, may be considered as a treatment for addiction, PTSD and brain injuries.
snippet: Some researchers hope the drug, still illegal in the United States, may be considered as a treatment for addiction, PTSD and brain injuries.
lead_paragraph: A naturally occurring psychoactive compound, ibogaine comes from the iboga tree, a rainforest shrub native to Central Africa. The drug comes from the bark of the root, which is crushed and consumed as a powder or given in an extracted form.

headline.main: What to Know About Ibogaine

abstract: New criteria could lead to a dementia diagnosis on the basis of a simple blood test, even in the absence of obvious symptoms.
snippet: New criteria could lead to a dementia diagnosis on the basis of a simple blood test, even in the absence of obvious symptoms.
lead_paragraph: Determining whether someone has Alzheimer's disease usually requires an extended diagnostic process. A doctor takes a patient's medical history, discusses symptoms, administers verbal and visual cognitive tests.

headline.main: Apparently Healthy, but Diagnosed With Alzheimer's?
headline.print_headline: Alzheimer's May Be Diagnosable Without Symptoms

abstract: For each additional minute spent with an electronic device, toddlers said less, heard less and had fewer back-and-forth exchanges with adults.
snippet: For each additional minute spent with an electronic device, toddlers said less, heard less and had fewer back-and-forth exchanges with adults.
lead_paragraph: According to new research, “technoference” is real.

headline.main: More Screen Time Means Less Parent-Child Talk, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Study Links Screens to Child-Parent Talk

abstract: DNA has shown that the extinct humans thrived around the world, from chilly Siberia to high-altitude Tibet — perhaps even in the Pacific islands.
snippet: DNA has shown that the extinct humans thrived around the world, from chilly Siberia to high-altitude Tibet — perhaps even in the Pacific islands.
lead_paragraph: Neanderthals may have vanished 40,000 years ago, but they are no strangers to us today. Their stocky skeletons dazzle in museums around the world. Their imagined personas star in television ads. When Kevin Bacon noted on Instagram that his morning habits are like those of a Neanderthal, he did not stop to explain that our ancient cousins interbred with modern humans expanding out of Africa.

headline.main: On the Trail of the Denisovans
headline.print_headline: Meet the Denisovans: Billions Have Their DNA

abstract: The arachnids, which are not spiders, were thought to have only two eyes, compared with many more on spiders.
snippet: The arachnids, which are not spiders, were thought to have only two eyes, compared with many more on spiders.
lead_paragraph: Guilherme Gainett, then a biologist at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, was looking through a microscope at the embryo of a daddy longlegs when he saw it — or, rather, saw them. Daddy longlegs, the group of splendidly leggy arachnids also known as harvestmen, have been thought to have just two eyes. But there on the animal's body, illuminated with fluorescent markers, were what looked like four more vestigial eyes.

headline.main: Daddy Longlegs Have Been Hiding Extra Eyes From Us
headline.print_headline: Seeing a Surplus: It Has Lots of Long Legs, Sure, but No Shortage of Eyes Either

abstract: Spikes of fatalities linked to drinking that began with the Covid pandemic were not an anomaly. An estimated 178,000 people died in 2021 from similar causes.
snippet: Spikes of fatalities linked to drinking that began with the Covid pandemic were not an anomaly. An estimated 178,000 people died in 2021 from similar causes.
lead_paragraph: Alcohol-related deaths surged in the United States by nearly 30 percent in recent years, with roughly 500 Americans dying each day in 2021, according to a new study published by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline.main: Alcohol-Related Deaths Surge to Nearly 500 a Day, C.D.C. Says

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

byline.original: By Christina Jewett and Jan Hoffman

abstract: A new study argues that Perucetus, an ancient whale species, was certainly big, but not as big as today's blue whales.
snippet: A new study argues that Perucetus, an ancient whale species, was certainly big, but not as big as today's blue whales.
lead_paragraph: Last August, a team of paleontologists announced that they had discovered the fossilized bones of a gigantic ancient whale. Perucetus, as they named it, might have weighed over 200 tons, which would make it the heaviest animal that has ever lived.

headline.main: Researchers Dispute Claim That Ancient Whale Was Heaviest Animal Ever
headline.print_headline: Heavy Loads: 60 Tons, and What Do You Get? Another 200 Tons or So Short of a Blue Whale.

abstract: A study suggests that humans often misinterpret a pet's signals; even purring doesn't guarantee a contented cat.
snippet: A study suggests that humans often misinterpret a pet's signals; even purring doesn't guarantee a contented cat.
lead_paragraph: What is the meaning of a cat's meow that grows louder and louder? Or your pet's sudden flip from softly purring as you stroke its back to biting your hand?

headline.main: It's the Cat's Meow but You Just Don't Understand
headline.print_headline: Language Barrier: Exactly What Part of Meow Don't You Understand?

abstract: A new study analyzed several years of surveys on  increases in marijuana and cannabis consumption.
snippet: A new study analyzed several years of surveys on  increases in marijuana and cannabis consumption.
lead_paragraph: People who frequently smoke marijuana have a higher risk of heart attack and stroke, according to a study published on Wednesday.

headline.main: Frequent Marijuana Use May Raise Risk of Heart Attack, Study Suggests

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Journal of the American Heart Assn

abstract: People with long Covid symptoms scored slightly lower on a cognitive test than people who had recovered. But long Covid patients who eventually got better scored as well as those whose symptoms did not last long.
snippet: People with long Covid symptoms scored slightly lower on a cognitive test than people who had recovered. But long Covid patients who eventually got better scored as well as those whose symptoms did not last long.
lead_paragraph: Long Covid may lead to measurable cognitive decline, especially in the ability to remember, reason and plan, a large new study suggests.

headline.main: Long Covid May Lead to Measurable Cognitive Decline, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Long Covid Linked to Cognitive Decline

abstract: For 40 years, Dr. Jane Burns has been working to find the cause of Kawasaki disease, an illness that can lead to aneurysms and heart attacks. Her work has brought together a most unlikely team.
snippet: For 40 years, Dr. Jane Burns has been working to find the cause of Kawasaki disease, an illness that can lead to aneurysms and heart attacks. Her work has brought together a most unlikely team.
lead_paragraph: It looked like a scene from the TV crime show “CSI.” Dr. Jane Burns was peering into a multiheaded microscope at the San Diego County medical examiner's office, scrutinizing autopsy samples from an array of mysterious deaths.

headline.main: A Doctor's Lifelong Quest to Solve One of Pediatric Medicine's Greatest Mysteries
headline.print_headline: Pursuing a Pediatric Mystery

byline.original: By Emily Baumgaertner and Ariana Drehsler

abstract: A new study using simulations suggests the impact in 2022 transformed the space rock into an M&M-like flat-top oval.
snippet: A new study using simulations suggests the impact in 2022 transformed the space rock into an M&M-like flat-top oval.
lead_paragraph: In 2022, when NASA's $325 million spacecraft crashed into an asteroid named Dimorphos at 14,000 miles per hour, cheers and applause erupted back on Earth.

headline.main: NASA's Crash Into an Asteroid May Have Altered Its Shape
headline.print_headline: NASA's Crash Into Asteroid May Have Flattened It

abstract: Xolair cuts the risk of dangerous reactions after exposure to minute amounts of allergens, researchers reported. But people taking it still must avoid risky foods.
snippet: Xolair cuts the risk of dangerous reactions after exposure to minute amounts of allergens, researchers reported. But people taking it still must avoid risky foods.
lead_paragraph: A drug that has been used for decades to treat allergic asthma and hives significantly reduced the risk of life-threatening reactions in children with severe food allergies who were exposed to trace amounts of peanuts, cashews, milk and eggs, researchers reported on Sunday.

headline.main: Drug Drastically Reduces Children's Reactions to Traces of Food Allergens
headline.print_headline: Drug Slashes Risk of Food Reactions in Children, Study Says

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: American Academy of Allergy Asthma and Immunology

abstract: The drug does not completely prevent reactions, but it can reduce the risks posed by trace amounts of food allergens.
snippet: The drug does not completely prevent reactions, but it can reduce the risks posed by trace amounts of food allergens.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration approved a drug this month that cuts the risk of severe reactions in children and adults exposed to trace amounts of peanuts, tree nuts, milk, dairy and other food allergens — a move that could dramatically improve quality of life for people coping with these risks. The results of the clinical trial supporting the decision were published on Sunday.

headline.main: What to Know About Xolair and Food Allergies
headline.print_headline: New Protection For Patients With Allergies Has High Costs

abstract: The F.D.A. recently approved the first therapy for patients in danger of losing their toes, fingers and other exposed parts of the body.
snippet: The F.D.A. recently approved the first therapy for patients in danger of losing their toes, fingers and other exposed parts of the body.
lead_paragraph: The first time Dr. Peter Hackett saw a patient with frostbite, the man died from his wounds. It was in Chicago in 1971, and the man had gotten drunk and passed out in the snow, his fingers so frozen that gangrene eventually set in.

headline.main: Severe Frostbite Gets a Treatment That May Prevent Amputation
headline.print_headline: A New Treatment For Severe Frostbite

abstract: Freezing water with salt or other impurities yields ice that is easier to loosen from a surface, according to a new study.
snippet: Freezing water with salt or other impurities yields ice that is easier to loosen from a surface, according to a new study.
lead_paragraph: What's the worst part of winter? The perpetual shoveling of snow? The bitter wind that whips across your face?

headline.main: Dirty Ice May Be Ugly, but It Has One Advantage
headline.print_headline: Clear Advantage: On Dirty Ice, Fewer Somersaults

abstract: As public health groups pressure the Biden administration to impose a ban on menthol cigarettes, research suggests similar moves in other countries have led to lower smoking rates.
snippet: As public health groups pressure the Biden administration to impose a ban on menthol cigarettes, research suggests similar moves in other countries have led to lower smoking rates.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a quarter of menthol cigarette smokers quit in the year or two after a ban on menthol went into effect, according to a study published on Wednesday.

headline.main: A Quarter of Smokers Quit Under Menthol Bans, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Smoking Rates Fell After a Ban on Menthol Cigarettes

abstract: Unusual experiments on organs recovered from three carcasses suggest how baleen whales call out at sea.
snippet: Unusual experiments on organs recovered from three carcasses suggest how baleen whales call out at sea.
lead_paragraph: People have told stories of strange underwater sounds for thousands of years, but it took until the mid-20th century for scientists to pinpoint one of the causes: whales, singing and whistling and squeaking in the blue.

headline.main: These Whales Still Use Their Vocal Cords. But How?
headline.print_headline: Big Voices: These Whales Still Use Their Vocal Cords. But How?

abstract: N.I.H. researchers found notable differences between the immune systems and other physiological functions of patients with ME/CFS and those of healthy patients.
snippet: N.I.H. researchers found notable differences between the immune systems and other physiological functions of patients with ME/CFS and those of healthy patients.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Caldwell was active and energetic, working two jobs and taking care of her daughter and her parents, when she developed a bacterial infection that was followed by intense lightheadedness, fatigue and memory problems.

headline.main: Study of Patients With a Chronic Fatigue Condition May Offer Clues to Long Covid
headline.print_headline: Chronic Fatigue Study May Help With Long Covid

abstract: The discovery may help shed light on how prehistoric societies treated children with rare conditions.
snippet: The discovery may help shed light on how prehistoric societies treated children with rare conditions.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have diagnosed Down syndrome from DNA in the ancient bones of seven infants, one as old as 5,500 years. Their method, published in the journal Nature Communications, may help researchers learn more about how prehistoric societies treated people with Down syndrome and other rare conditions.

headline.main: Scientists Find Genetic Signature of Down Syndrome in Ancient Bones
headline.print_headline: Ancient Bones Reveal Down Syndrome Signs

abstract: Some of the best known species on Earth may not be what they seem.
snippet: Some of the best known species on Earth may not be what they seem.
lead_paragraph: Naturalists have been trying for centuries to catalog all of the species on Earth, and the effort remains one of the great unfinished jobs in science. So far, researchers have named about 2.3 million species, but there are millions — perhaps even billions — left to be discovered.

headline.main: What Is a Species, Anyway?
headline.print_headline: Defining A Species Is Open To Debate

abstract: A society in which members of different generations do not interact “is a dangerous experiment,” said one researcher.
snippet: A society in which members of different generations do not interact “is a dangerous experiment,” said one researcher.
lead_paragraph: On Fridays at 10 a.m., Richard Bement and Zach Ahmed sign on to their weekly video chat. The program that brought them together provides online discussion prompts and suggests arts-related activities, but the two largely ignore all that.

headline.main: Old and Young, Talking Again
headline.print_headline: The Upside of Leaning In to the Generation Gap

abstract: Three studies have recently explored toe-tapping, which seems to have something to do with frogs preying on insects.
snippet: Three studies have recently explored toe-tapping, which seems to have something to do with frogs preying on insects.
lead_paragraph: Faster than Gene Kelly tap-dancing in the rain, many species of poison dart frogs tap their middle toes on their hind feet so rapidly it can look like a blur.

headline.main: Poison Frogs Have a Strange Behavior That Scientists Seek to Explain
headline.print_headline: Poisonous Feeling: Tap, Tap, Tapping to the Beat Of an Impossibly Fast Drummer

abstract: The quiet withdrawal of a 2021 cancer study by Dr. Sam Yoon highlights scientific publishers' lack of transparency around data problems.
snippet: The quiet withdrawal of a 2021 cancer study by Dr. Sam Yoon highlights scientific publishers' lack of transparency around data problems.
lead_paragraph: The stomach cancer study was shot through with suspicious data. Identical constellations of cells were said to depict separate experiments on wholly different biological lineages. Photos of tumor-stricken mice, used to show that a drug reduced cancer growth, had been featured in two previous papers describing other treatments.

headline.main: A Columbia Surgeon's Study Was Pulled. He Kept Publishing Flawed Data.
headline.print_headline: Cancer Doctor Is in Spotlight Over Bad Data

abstract: Researchers analyzed the experiences of more than 6,000 women and found the method to be 98 percent effective and safe for 99 percent of patients.
snippet: Researchers analyzed the experiences of more than 6,000 women and found the method to be 98 percent effective and safe for 99 percent of patients.
lead_paragraph: Taking abortion pills prescribed through telemedicine and received by mail — a method used by growing numbers of abortion patients — is as safe and effective as when the pills are obtained by visiting a doctor, a large new study found. The method was about 98 percent effective and was safe for over 99 percent of patients, the study reported.

headline.main: Abortions by Telemedicine and Mailed Pills Are Safe and Effective, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Telemedicine Abortion Services Are as Safe as Visiting a Clinic, Study Finds

abstract: About 8,200 years ago, in one of the last places settled by humans, prehistoric peoples began painting comblike designs as the climate shifted.
snippet: About 8,200 years ago, in one of the last places settled by humans, prehistoric peoples began painting comblike designs as the climate shifted.
lead_paragraph: In the stark inland desert of Patagonia in Argentina, there is a remote cave decorated with nearly 900 paintings of human figures, animals and abstract designs. Until recently, archaeologists had assumed that the rock art at this site, known as Cueva Huenul 1, was created within the past few thousand years.

headline.main: Mysterious Pattern in a Cave Is Oldest Rock Art Found in Patagonia
headline.print_headline: Parting Shots: For Ancient Patagonian Painters, a Fixation With Combs

abstract: Some female birds, reptiles and other animals can make a baby on their own. But for mammals like us, eggs and sperm need each other.
snippet: Some female birds, reptiles and other animals can make a baby on their own. But for mammals like us, eggs and sperm need each other.
lead_paragraph: If Galentine's Day had an animal mascot, it would have to be one of the species whose females can reproduce without a mate. Nearly all animals make more of themselves the traditional way, by combining eggs and sperm. But some have an alternative called parthenogenesis: no males needed.

headline.main: Self-Love Is Important, but We Mammals Are Stuck With Sex
headline.print_headline: Genetics Keeps Mammals Pairing Up to Breed

abstract: Today's birds began their evolution into more than 10,000 species long before the fateful collision, a new genetic study found.
snippet: Today's birds began their evolution into more than 10,000 species long before the fateful collision, a new genetic study found.
lead_paragraph: Sixty-six million years ago, an asteroid slammed into the Gulf of Mexico. The catastrophe led to the extinction of as many as three-quarters of all species on Earth, including dinosaurs like Tyrannosaurus rex. But some flying feathered dinosaurs survived, and eventually evolved into the more than 10,000 species of birds living today, including hummingbirds, condors, parrots and owls.

headline.main: An Asteroid Wiped Out Dinosaurs. Did It Help Birds Flourish?
headline.print_headline: Long Before a Catastrophe, Birds Were Diversifying

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

abstract: Maybe frog and fungi are friends.
snippet: Maybe frog and fungi are friends.
lead_paragraph: Over the summer, Lohit Y.T., a river and wetlands specialist at World Wildlife Fund-India, set off with his friends in the drizzly foothills of the Western Ghats in India. They had one goal: to see amphibians and reptiles.

headline.main: A Mushroom Grew in a Strange Place: The Side of a Frog
headline.print_headline: A Frog That Always Brings His Fungi Along

abstract: Astronomers tracked the entry of a small space rock into Earth's atmosphere, and then meteorite hunters made an unexpected discovery.
snippet: Astronomers tracked the entry of a small space rock into Earth's atmosphere, and then meteorite hunters made an unexpected discovery.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have found pieces of a meteorite that fell near Berlin just after midnight on Jan. 21. It is a rare find, from an asteroid that was identified just before it entered Earth's atmosphere. Only a handful of such events in the recent past have allowed astronomers to trace an incoming rock's origin in the solar system.

headline.main: Fragments of Asteroid With Mystery Origin Are Found Outside Berlin
headline.print_headline: Meteoric Mystery: Origin of Space Rocks in Berlin? Maybe Express Delivery From Mercury.

abstract: The journal found that the studies, which had suggested that medication abortion is unsafe, included incorrect factual assumptions and misleading presentation of the data.
snippet: The journal found that the studies, which had suggested that medication abortion is unsafe, included incorrect factual assumptions and misleading presentation of the data.
lead_paragraph: An academic journal publisher this week retracted two studies that were cited by a federal judge in Texas last year when he ruled that the abortion pill mifepristone should be taken off the market.

headline.main: Journal Retracts Studies Cited in Federal Court Ruling Against Abortion Pill
headline.print_headline: Publisher Retracts Studies Cited in Abortion Ruling

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Health Services Research and Managerial Epidemiology (Journal)

abstract: In an unlikely act of altruism observed two years ago, a male elephant seal prevented a younger animal from drowning.
snippet: In an unlikely act of altruism observed two years ago, a male elephant seal prevented a younger animal from drowning.
lead_paragraph: Male elephant seals are not known for their paternal instincts. While splayed out on the beach during the breeding season, these far-from-gentle giants focus on mating with females and fighting other males. As they hustle their two tons of bulk around the colony in pursuit of these goals, “they'll run over pups” without hesitation, crushing even their own offspring, said Daniel Costa, an ecologist at the University of California, Santa Cruz.

headline.main: A Two-Ton Lifeguard That Saved a Young Pup
headline.print_headline: Big-Hearted: To the Rescue of a Seal Pup, a Two-Ton Lifeguard

abstract: The second of a pair of close flybys adds to the treasure trove of data that scientists have about Jupiter's volcanic moon.
snippet: The second of a pair of close flybys adds to the treasure trove of data that scientists have about Jupiter's volcanic moon.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, NASA's Juno orbiter got a second close-up with Io, Jupiter's third-largest moon and the most volcanic world of our solar system.

headline.main: NASA Spots Signs of Twin Volcanic Plumes on Jupiter's Moon Io
headline.print_headline: Hellish Landscape: On Jupiter's Io, a Glimpse of Volcanic Plumes

abstract: Scientists discovered a species off the Alabama coast that is part of group of mussels never before seen at such shallow depths.
snippet: Scientists discovered a species off the Alabama coast that is part of group of mussels never before seen at such shallow depths.
lead_paragraph: The creature was tiny, about the size and color of a grain of rice. Dan Distel, director of the Ocean Genome Legacy Center at Northeastern University in Boston, wasn't exactly sure what it was, other than a mussel of some kind. He put the wee bivalve in a petri dish and asked a colleague to set it aside.

headline.main: A New Creature Emerges From a Forest Drowned by the Gulf of Mexico
headline.print_headline: Mussel Shores New Creature Emerges Out of an Underwater Forest

abstract: Receiving multidose vaccinations in both arms, instead of just one, may increase the immune response, new research suggests.
snippet: Receiving multidose vaccinations in both arms, instead of just one, may increase the immune response, new research suggests.
lead_paragraph: If you've presented the same arm for every dose of a particular vaccine, you may want to reconsider. Alternating arms may produce a more powerful immune response, a new study suggests.

headline.main: One Arm or Two? How You Get Vaccinated May Make a Difference.
headline.print_headline: Alternating Your Arms For Shots May Help

abstract: Black people in the U.S. were far more likely to report harmfully low sleep in the months after a killing compared with white people surveyed during that time.
snippet: Black people in the U.S. were far more likely to report harmfully low sleep in the months after a killing compared with white people surveyed during that time.
lead_paragraph: Black people in the United States are more likely than white people to report that they do not sleep much, research shows. On average, they live in louder neighborhoods, work longer hours and pick up more late-night shifts — concerning to public health experts, since sleep deprivation is linked to chronic health issues and early death.

headline.main: After Police Kill Unarmed Black People, Sleep Worsens — but Only for Black People
headline.print_headline: Black People Sleep Worse After Police Violence, Study Says

abstract: The patients used tirzepatide, sold as Mounjaro or Zepbound, but researchers could not distinguish the effect of the drug from the effects of weight loss.
snippet: The patients used tirzepatide, sold as Mounjaro or Zepbound, but researchers could not distinguish the effect of the drug from the effects of weight loss.
lead_paragraph: A study of the weight loss drug tirzepatide showed that people who took it had significantly lower blood pressures after 36 weeks of using the medication.

headline.main: Users of New Weight Loss Drug Had Lower Blood Pressure in Study
headline.print_headline: User of Weight Loss Drug Had Lower Blood Pressure

abstract: The toilet brushlike specimen from a Canadian quarry hints at the evolutionary experiments that occurred during a 15-million-year gap in the fossil record.
snippet: The toilet brushlike specimen from a Canadian quarry hints at the evolutionary experiments that occurred during a 15-million-year gap in the fossil record.
lead_paragraph: In the ancient prehistory of Earth, there is a chapter that waits to be told known as Romer's gap. Researchers have identified a hiatus in the tetrapod fossil record between 360 million and 345 million years ago, after fish had begun to adapt to land and more than 80 million years before the first dinosaurs.

headline.main: A Fossilized Tree That Dr. Seuss Might Have Dreamed Up
headline.print_headline: The Shock in the Rock: A Fossilized Tree That Dr. Seuss  Might Have Dreamed Up

abstract: Meet Sholto David, whose error-spotting has raised a question: If researchers aren't getting the little things right, what else might be wrong?
snippet: Meet Sholto David, whose error-spotting has raised a question: If researchers aren't getting the little things right, what else might be wrong?
lead_paragraph: Sholto David, 32, has a Ph.D. in cellular and molecular biology from Newcastle University in England. He is also developing an expertise in spotting errors in scientific papers. Most recently, and notably, he discovered flawed or manipulated data in studies conducted by top executives at the Harvard-affiliated Dana-Farber Cancer Institute. The institute said that it was requesting retraction of six manuscripts and had found 31 other manuscripts that required corrections.

headline.main: He Hunts Sloppy Scientists. He's Finding Lots of Prey.
headline.print_headline: Catching Too Many Errors by Sloppy Scientists

abstract: The material can be tempered into different shapes — like steel in the hands of a blacksmith — and could someday transform space travel, recycling and more.
snippet: The material can be tempered into different shapes — like steel in the hands of a blacksmith — and could someday transform space travel, recycling and more.
lead_paragraph: With restrictions on space and weight, what would you bring if you were going to Mars? An ideal option might be a single material that can shift shapes into any object you imagine.

headline.main: A Shape-Shifting Plastic With a Flexible Future
headline.print_headline: A Plastic Redefines Flexibility

abstract: Small dogs with prominent noses live longer than bigger, flat-faced canines, a new study suggests.
snippet: Small dogs with prominent noses live longer than bigger, flat-faced canines, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: All dogs go to heaven. But a bulldog might find itself headed there years before a Border terrier, according to a new study of nearly 600,000 British dogs from more than 150 breeds.

headline.main: The Dogs That Live Longest, by a Nose
headline.print_headline: Study of Dogs Reveals the Contours of Longevity

abstract: The molecules that silence a woman's second X chromosome can confuse the immune system, a new study suggests.
snippet: The molecules that silence a woman's second X chromosome can confuse the immune system, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: Women are much more likely than men to have their immune system turn against them, resulting in an array of so-called autoimmune diseases, like lupus and multiple sclerosis. A study published on Thursday offers an explanation rooted in the X chromosome.

headline.main: Why Do Women Have More Autoimmune Diseases? Study Points to X Chromosome
headline.print_headline: A Clue to Women's Higher Rate of Autoimmune Disease

abstract: What paleontologists long believed were long spines on the aptly named Alienacanthus turn out to be an extended lower jaw.
snippet: What paleontologists long believed were long spines on the aptly named Alienacanthus turn out to be an extended lower jaw.
lead_paragraph: Some 375 million years ago, armored fishes ruled a watery world. Known as placoderms, these primitive jawed vertebrates came in all shapes and sizes, from small bottom-dwellers to giant filter-feeders. Some, like the wrecking-ball-shaped Dunkleosteus, were among the ocean's earliest apex predators.

headline.main: This Ancient Fish Gave the Whole Ocean the Stiff Lower Lip
headline.print_headline: Oversize Underbite: Not Showing as Much Spine, but Keeping a Very Stiff Lower Lip

abstract: A study offers the latest evidence of the problem-solving prowess of the clever birds.
snippet: A study offers the latest evidence of the problem-solving prowess of the clever birds.
lead_paragraph: Rosy-faced lovebirds are charismatic, petite parrots. They also aren't afraid to use their heads — literally — to get around an awkward situation.

headline.main: Parrots Use Their Beaks to Swing Like Monkeys
headline.print_headline: Low-Wire Act: See What Monkeys Do? Parrots Can Do It Too.

abstract: Dozens of people, including babies, were sickened, according to a C.D.C. study that highlighted the risks of snuggling with the strikingly scaly lizards, many of which carry salmonella bacteria in their gut.
snippet: Dozens of people, including babies, were sickened, according to a C.D.C. study that highlighted the risks of snuggling with the strikingly scaly lizards, many of which carry salmonella bacteria in their gut.
lead_paragraph: The outbreak of a rare strain of salmonella that sickened scores of people, including several infants, across the United States and Canada, has been linked to pet bearded dragons, some most likely obtained from the same breeder in Southeast Asia, according to a study published by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline.main: Pet Dragons Linked to Rare Salmonella Strain in U.S. and Canada
headline.print_headline: Pet Dragons Linked to Rare Salmonella Strain in U.S. and Canada

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

abstract: Scientists find that male antechinuses, rodent-like animals from Australia, will forgo sleep for sex during their breeding season, after which they die.
snippet: Scientists find that male antechinuses, rodent-like animals from Australia, will forgo sleep for sex during their breeding season, after which they die.
lead_paragraph: Scurrying along the dense brush of coastal woodlands and forests, the small, mouselike antechinus appears more unassuming than many of Australia's marsupials. But for the three weeks of their breeding season, the males transform into absolute sex-obsessed lotharios.

headline.main: The Sex-Obsessed Marsupials That Will Sleep When They're Dead
headline.print_headline: Macho Marsupial: He's For Sex, Sex, Sex Till Death Do Us Part

abstract: Scientists studied how thresher sharks use “extreme yoga” to whip their tails at prey.
snippet: Scientists studied how thresher sharks use “extreme yoga” to whip their tails at prey.
lead_paragraph: When a thresher shark attacks, it doesn't lunge in teeth-first. Instead, it approaches a school of fish, lowers its head, flexes its body and thwaps its whiplike tail over its head. The smack of the thresher's tail stuns a few unlucky fish, which the shark then gobbles up.

headline.main: Fear the Tails, Not the Jaws, of These 'Weirdo' Sharks
headline.print_headline: Flipping the Script: Fear the Tails, Not the Jaws,  Of These 'Weirdo' Sharks

abstract: The genetic treatment targeted a particular kind of congenital deafness and will soon be tried in children who are younger.
snippet: The genetic treatment targeted a particular kind of congenital deafness and will soon be tried in children who are younger.
lead_paragraph: Aissam Dam, an 11-year-old boy, grew up in a world of profound silence. He was born deaf and had never heard anything. While living in a poor community in Morocco, he expressed himself with a sign language he invented and had no schooling.

headline.main: Gene Therapy Allows an 11-Year-Old Boy to Hear for the First Time
headline.print_headline: Innovative Use of Gene Therapy Lets Boy Hear for the First Time

abstract: A British biologist and blogger discovered faulty data in many studies conducted by top executives of the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute.
snippet: A British biologist and blogger discovered faulty data in many studies conducted by top executives of the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute.
lead_paragraph: A prominent cancer center affiliated with Harvard said it will ask medical journals to retract six research papers and correct dozens of others after a British scientist and blogger found that work by some of its top executives was rife with duplicated or manipulated data.

headline.main: Top Cancer Center Seeks to Retract or Correct Dozens of Studies
headline.print_headline: Dana-Farber Cancer Institute Seeks to Retract or Correct Dozens of Flawed Studies

abstract: Coronary artery bypass grafting, the most common cardiac procedure in the United States, was studied mostly in men. Women are paying the price.
snippet: Coronary artery bypass grafting, the most common cardiac procedure in the United States, was studied mostly in men. Women are paying the price.
lead_paragraph: Last Thanksgiving, Cynthia Mosson had been on her feet all day in her kitchen in Frankfort, Ind., preparing dinner for nine. She was nearly finished — the ham in the oven, the dressing made — when she suddenly felt the need to sit down.

headline.main: The Heart Surgery That Isn't as Safe for Older Women
headline.print_headline: The Heart Surgery That Isn't as Safe for Women

abstract: Newly released documents indicate that a U.S. genetic database had received the sequence of the coronavirus two weeks before it was made public by others.
snippet: Newly released documents indicate that a U.S. genetic database had received the sequence of the coronavirus two weeks before it was made public by others.
lead_paragraph: In late December 2019, eight pages of genetic code were sent to computers at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md.

headline.main: Before the Coronavirus Pandemic, Overlooked Clues From Chinese Scientists
headline.print_headline: Early Clue to Coronavirus From China Was Overlooked, Then Deleted

abstract: Scientists are looking at layers of minerals left behind on mammoth tusks to estimate where the hulking animals spent their days.
snippet: Scientists are looking at layers of minerals left behind on mammoth tusks to estimate where the hulking animals spent their days.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have written the biography of a 14,000-year-old female woolly mammoth by analyzing the chemicals in her tusk.

headline.main: An Ancient Woolly Mammoth Left a Diary in Her Tusk
headline.print_headline: Mammoth Trail Guide Discovered

abstract: The American Cancer Society found many deaths prevented, but an uptick in incidence of a variety of cancers.
snippet: The American Cancer Society found many deaths prevented, but an uptick in incidence of a variety of cancers.
lead_paragraph: Cancer deaths in the United States are falling, with four million deaths prevented since 1991, according to the American Cancer Society's annual report.

headline.main: Cancer Deaths Are Falling, but There May Be an Asterisk
headline.print_headline: Fewer Dying From Cancer, Yet an Uptick

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Journal of the American Medical Assn

abstract: Researchers found that the slime eel, or hagfish, known for deluging predators with mucus, tripled the size of its genome hundreds of millions of years ago.
snippet: Researchers found that the slime eel, or hagfish, known for deluging predators with mucus, tripled the size of its genome hundreds of millions of years ago.
lead_paragraph: The hagfish, a deep-sea scavenger about the size and shape of a tube sock, has the curious ability to smother itself in its own snot. The mucus is a defense mechanism, released into the water (or in one unfortunate incident, all over an Oregon highway) when the fish feels threatened. Once it hits seawater, a tiny amount of the ooze expands to 10,000 times its original size in a fraction of a second, forming a tenacious web of goo. A shark trying to take a bite of a hagfish will find itself suddenly unable to breathe, its gills clogged with the slime.

headline.main: The Ancient Back Story of the Slimiest Animal in the Sea
headline.print_headline: Slimy is as Slimy Does: When Encountering The Gooiest Creature, Best Not Stick Around

abstract: An Oxford researcher measured the effect of popular workplace mental health interventions, and discovered little to none.
snippet: An Oxford researcher measured the effect of popular workplace mental health interventions, and discovered little to none.
lead_paragraph: Employee mental health services have become a billion-dollar industry. New hires, once they have found the restrooms and enrolled in 401(k) plans, are presented with a panoply of digital wellness solutions, mindfulness seminars, massage classes, resilience workshops, coaching sessions and sleep apps.

headline.main: Workplace Wellness Programs Have Little Benefit, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Workplace Wellness Programs Are of Little Benefit to Employees, Study Finds

abstract: The stream of helium trailing WASP-69b, a “Hot Jupiter,” allows astronomers to study how planets lose their atmospheres.
snippet: The stream of helium trailing WASP-69b, a “Hot Jupiter,” allows astronomers to study how planets lose their atmospheres.
lead_paragraph: Humanity has spied more than 5,500 worlds orbiting other stars, and some are truly exotic. One seems to have titanium clouds, while on another, storms of glass may rain down.

headline.main: This Distant Planet Has a 350,000-Mile-Long Cometlike Tail
headline.print_headline: Cosmic Attachment: Trailing WASP-69b, a Caboose That's a Moonshot and a Half Long

abstract: Researchers say the species they named Tyrannosaurus mcraeensis predated the dinosaur era's great predator.
snippet: Researchers say the species they named Tyrannosaurus mcraeensis predated the dinosaur era's great predator.
lead_paragraph: A team of researchers have announced the discovery of a new species of Tyrannosaurus from New Mexico, one that appeared in the fossil record five million to seven million years before the familiar tyrant lizard. Their research, published Thursday in the journal Scientific Reports, suggests a new chapter could be added to the origin story of Tyrannosaurus rex.

headline.main: New Origin Story for Tyrannosaurus Rex Suggested by Fossil
headline.print_headline: What Came Before Tyrannosaurus Rex

abstract: The specimen came from a 289 million-year-old fossil deposit and might offer clues to how skin evolved.
snippet: The specimen came from a 289 million-year-old fossil deposit and might offer clues to how skin evolved.
lead_paragraph: Dry, scaly skin may be one of the least fun parts of winter. But in the broad scheme of things, a tough, watertight hide is part of what enabled the ancestors of modern reptiles, birds and mammals to move inland while their thin-skinned amphibian cousins remained close to water.

headline.main: Scaly Fossil Is the Oldest-Known Piece of Skin
headline.print_headline: From Ancient Fossil, a Skin-Deep Discovery

abstract: The National Institute on Aging may let funding lapse for a yearslong study of nearly 50,000 pet dogs, which could also offer insight into human health.
snippet: The National Institute on Aging may let funding lapse for a yearslong study of nearly 50,000 pet dogs, which could also offer insight into human health.
lead_paragraph: In late 2019, scientists began searching for 10,000 Americans willing to enroll their pets in an ambitious new study of health and longevity in dogs. The researchers planned to track the dogs over the course of their lives, collecting detailed information about their bodies, lifestyles and home environments. Over time, the scientists hoped to identify the biological and environmental factors that kept some dogs healthy in their golden years — and uncover insights about aging that could help both dogs and humans lead longer, healthier lives.

headline.main: Scientists Scramble to Keep Dog Aging Project Alive
headline.print_headline: Scientists Scramble to Keep Dog Aging Project Alive

abstract: Two studies concluded that depression that began in pregnancy or soon after could have troubling implications for as long as 18 years.
snippet: Two studies concluded that depression that began in pregnancy or soon after could have troubling implications for as long as 18 years.
lead_paragraph: Women who experience depression during pregnancy or in the year after giving birth have a greater risk of suicide and attempted suicide — risks that persist for years, two new studies report.

headline.main: Women With Depression During or After Pregnancy Face Greater Suicide Risk, Even Years Later
headline.print_headline: Women With Depression During or After Pregnancy Face Greater Prolonged Suicide Risk

abstract: Fossil teeth reveal Gigantopithecus was doomed by a changing environment and an inflexible diet.
snippet: Fossil teeth reveal Gigantopithecus was doomed by a changing environment and an inflexible diet.
lead_paragraph: Standing nearly as tall as a basketball hoop and weighing as much as a grizzly bear, Gigantopithecus blacki was the greatest ape to ever live. For more than a million years during the Pleistocene, Gigantopithecus roamed southern China. But by the time ancient humans reached the region, Gigantopithecus had vanished.

headline.main: The Biggest Ape That Ever Lived Was Not Too Big to Fail
headline.print_headline: The Largest Ape Ever, but Not Too Big to Fail

abstract: DNA fragments from thousands of years ago are providing insights into multiple sclerosis, diabetes, schizophrenia and other illnesses.
snippet: DNA fragments from thousands of years ago are providing insights into multiple sclerosis, diabetes, schizophrenia and other illnesses.
lead_paragraph: Multiple sclerosis, an autoimmune disease that affects 2.9 million people, presents a biological puzzle.

headline.main: Ancient Skeletons Give Clues to Modern Medical Mysteries
headline.print_headline: Clues to Modern Medical Mysteries in Ancient Bones

abstract: After dropping two Harvard experts who had received industry support, the National Academies turned to a colleague with a similar background.
snippet: After dropping two Harvard experts who had received industry support, the National Academies turned to a colleague with a similar background.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after dropping two Harvard scientists with financial conflicts of interest, the national organization assembling a committee to assess the evidence about drinking and health has chosen four new panelists, among them another Harvard professor who also has financial ties to the alcohol industry.

headline.main: U.S. Diet Panel Adds Another Researcher With Alcohol Industry Ties
headline.print_headline: Panel Studying Alcohol Use Adds Analyst Tied to Industry

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine

abstract: The effects of drugs that treat Alzheimer's, cancer and other illnesses are often limited by the blood-brain barrier. A small study suggests a way forward.
snippet: The effects of drugs that treat Alzheimer's, cancer and other illnesses are often limited by the blood-brain barrier. A small study suggests a way forward.
lead_paragraph: There is a problem with the recently approved Alzheimer's drug, Aduhelm. It can remove some of the amyloid that forms brain plaques that are hallmarks of the disease. But most of the drug is wasted because it hits an obstacle, the blood-brain barrier, that protects the brain from toxins and infections but also prevents many drugs from entering.

headline.main: An Ultrasound Experiment Tackles a Giant Problem in Brain Medicine
headline.print_headline: Experiment Tackles a Big Problem in Brain Medicine

abstract: Earth's stratosphere has never seen the amounts of emissions and waste from rockets and satellites that a booming space economy will leave behind.
snippet: Earth's stratosphere has never seen the amounts of emissions and waste from rockets and satellites that a booming space economy will leave behind.
lead_paragraph: The high-altitude chase started over Cape Canaveral on Feb. 17, 2023, when a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket launched. Thomas Parent, a NASA research pilot, was flying a WB-57 jet when the rocket ascended past the right wing — leaving him mesmerized before he hit the throttle to accelerate.

headline.main: The New Space Race Is Causing New Pollution Problems
headline.print_headline: Filling Up a New Frontier

abstract: Scientists recently analyzed a Peruvian 10-cent piece with an unexplained origin.
snippet: Scientists recently analyzed a Peruvian 10-cent piece with an unexplained origin.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, a funny money mystery fell into the hands of scientists and students at the Pontifical Catholic University of Peru in Lima.

headline.main: The Mystery of the Coin That Shouldn't Exist
headline.print_headline: Peruvian Puzzler: The Case of the Doubtful Dinero

abstract: The research, supported by the National Institutes of Health, may reassure some patients after a European drug safety agency raised concerns last year.
snippet: The research, supported by the National Institutes of Health, may reassure some patients after a European drug safety agency raised concerns last year.
lead_paragraph: People taking the wildly popular drugs Ozempic, to treat diabetes, and Wegovy, to combat obesity, are slightly less likely to have suicidal thoughts than people who are not taking them, researchers reported on Friday.

headline.main: Ozempic and Wegovy Users Had Less Risk of Suicidal Thoughts in Large Study
headline.print_headline: 2 Drugs Show A Lower Risk Of Thoughts Of Suicide

abstract: Neptune is not as blue as you've been led to believe, and Uranus's shifting colors are better explained, in new research.
snippet: Neptune is not as blue as you've been led to believe, and Uranus's shifting colors are better explained, in new research.
lead_paragraph: Think of Uranus and Neptune, the solar system's outermost planets, and you may picture two distinct hues: pale turquoise and cobalt blue. But astronomers say that the true colors of these distant ice giants are more similar than their popular depictions.

headline.main: Uranus and Neptune Reveal Their True Colors
headline.print_headline: A Different Shading: Shedding Light On the True Colors Of Uranus and Neptune

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society (Journal)

abstract: With Covid deaths rising to about 1,500 per week, researchers question why Paxlovid use has remained low among high-risk patients.
snippet: With Covid deaths rising to about 1,500 per week, researchers question why Paxlovid use has remained low among high-risk patients.
lead_paragraph: As Covid rises again, killing about 1,500 Americans each week, medical researchers are trying to understand why so few people are taking Paxlovid, a medicine that is stunningly effective in preventing severe illness and death from the disease.

headline.main: Paxlovid Cuts Covid Death Risk. But Those Who Need It Are Not Taking It.
headline.print_headline: Few Take Paxlovid, Even as Covid Surges Again

abstract: Juno, a NASA mission designed to study Jupiter's origins, sent back new views of the most eruptive world in the solar system.
snippet: Juno, a NASA mission designed to study Jupiter's origins, sent back new views of the most eruptive world in the solar system.
lead_paragraph: A NASA spacecraft swooped past Io, one of Jupiter's largest moons and the most volcanically active world in our solar system. The spacecraft, the Juno orbiter, made its closest flyby yet of Io's turbulent landscape, and sent back snapshots speckled with sharp cliffs, edgy mountain peaks, lakes of pooled lava and even a volcanic plume.

headline.main: New Images of Jupiter's Moon Io Capture Infernal Volcanic Landscape
headline.print_headline: Snapshots of a Moon: Orbiting Jupiter, A Volcanic Dazzler

abstract: As the number of bees and other pollinators falls, field pansies are adapting by fertilizing their own seeds, a new study found.
snippet: As the number of bees and other pollinators falls, field pansies are adapting by fertilizing their own seeds, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: Every spring, trillions of flowers mate with the help of bees and other animals. They lure the pollinators to their flowers with flashy colors and nectar. As the animals travel from flower to flower, they take pollen with them, which can fertilize the seeds of other plants.

headline.main: Flowers Are Evolving to Have Less Sex
headline.print_headline: Flowers Are Quickly Evolving to Have Less Sex

abstract: New research is trying to remake the case that fossils known as Nanotyrannus were their own species, rather than a teenage Tyrannosaurus rex.
snippet: New research is trying to remake the case that fossils known as Nanotyrannus were their own species, rather than a teenage Tyrannosaurus rex.
lead_paragraph: It is only 23 inches long, but one tyrannosaur skull has been a bone of serious contention among paleontologists for decades.

headline.main: Study Aims to Bring a Tinier Tyrannosaur Back From Oblivion
headline.print_headline: Food for Thought: Study Aims to Bring Tinier (but Still Voracious) Tyrannosaur Back From Oblivion

abstract: Rates of requests were highest in states where abortion bans were expected.
snippet: Rates of requests were highest in states where abortion bans were expected.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of women who are not pregnant are ordering abortion pills just in case they might need them someday, especially in states where access is threatened, according to a study published on Tuesday.

headline.main: More Women Who Are Not Pregnant Are Ordering Abortion Pills Just in Case
